READ CAREFULLY! You may use this form to file a complaint. This form should be used if you, as an applicant for U.S. Department of the Interior (USDOI) employment or as a DOI employee, believe you have been discriminated against because of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, disability, or reprisal by the DOI. When filing a complaint, you should provide a statement of what occurred, when the incident(s) occurred, and why you believe you were treated in a discriminatory manner. Your complaint must bear an original signature.

<p>

COMPLAINTS PROCESSING INFORMATION

*Prior to filing a complaint, you must present the matter(s) that you believe are discriminatory to an EEO Counselor for informal resolution, within forty-five (45) calendar days from the date the incident occurred, or 45-calendar days from the effective date of a personnel action. The EEO Counselor has thirty (30) calendar days to attempt a resolution of the matter, and conduct a final interview with you. The EEO Counselor will notify you in writing of your right to file a formal complaint. You have fifteen (15) calendar days to file a formal complaint after receipt of the Notice of Final Interview (NOFI). The 15-day filing period may be waived if you show that you were not notified of the time limits for filing, or that you were prevented from meeting the time limits by circumstances beyond your control. Failure to file your complaint within the 15-calendar day period may result in the dismissal of your complaint.

*Your written complaint should be filed by you or your designated representative with the Equal Employment Opportunity Officer of the Bureau where the alleged discriminatory incident occurred, the Secretary of the Interior, or with the Director, Office of Civil Rights, U. S. Department of the Interior, 1849 C Street, N. W., MS-5230, MIB, Washington, D. C. 20240. If you choose to have a representative, you must designate the representative in writing, providing his/her full name and address.

*If your complaint is accepted for processing, the investigation should be completed within one hundred and eighty (180) calendar days from the filing date of your complaint. By written agreement, you and the Agency may extend the time period for no more than an additional ninety (90) calendar days. Following the investigation, the Agency will provide you a copy of the Report of Investigation (ROI). If the Agency fails to issue the ROI within 180-days of the filing date of your complaint, you may request a hearing.

Upon receipt of the ROI, you will have thirty (30) calendar days to request a hearing before an Administrative Judge (AJ) of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), or to request an immediate final decision from the DOI.

*If you choose a hearing, the EEOC Administrative Judge will issue a Statement of Findings and Conclusions, within 180-days of receipt of your hearing request, unless the AJ extends the time period for good cause. If you do not request either a hearing or a final decision within the 30-calendar day time period, the DOI will issue a final decision.

*The DOI will issue a final decision within sixty (60) calendar days from receipt of your request for a final decision. If the Administrative Judge issues a Statement of Findings and Conclusions, the DOI has forty (40) calendar days to appeal or accept the AJ’s findings and conclusions. If the DOI has not issued a final decision within 40-calendar days, the findings and conclusions of the Administrative Judge will become the DOI's Final Decision. If you are dissatisfied with the agency's final decision you may appeal the decision within thirty (30) calendar days of your receipt of the decision, to the EEOC, Office of Federal Operations, P.O. Box 19848, Washington, D.C. 20046.

*In lieu of an appeal to the EEOC, you may file a civil action in an appropriate U. S. District Court, within ninety (90) calendar days of your receipt of the final decision. Additionally, you may file a civil action after 180-calendar days have elapsed from the filing date of your complaint, if the Agency has not issued a final decision and no appeal has been filed.

*If you file an appeal with the EEOC and you are not satisfied with the EEOC's decision, you may file a civil action within

90-calendar days of your receipt of the EEOC's final decision. You may also file a civil action after 180-calendar days have elapsed from the filing date of your appeal, if the EEOC has not issued a final decision.

*If you file a civil action involving this complaint, you must specifically name the Secretary of the Interior as Defendant. Failure to do so may result in the loss of any judicial redress to which you may be entitled. Additionally, the filing of a civil action will terminate the agency's processing of your complaint, or the EEOC's processing of your appeal.

*There are special provisions in the regulations with respect to related processes, such as mixed case complaints, negotiated grievance procedures, class complaints, etc. For further information you may consult 29 Code of Federal Regulations (C.F.R.), Part 1614.

A. Disparate Treatment

Claims in which disparate treatment is alleged are adjudicated under the standards set forth by the U.S. Supreme Court in <a href="viewpage.html?_Page=LawOpinionsResearch_OpinionSCOTUS#caseMcDonnell-Douglas" target="_blank"><i>McDonnell Douglas v. Green,</i> 411 U.S. 792, 802 (1973).</a> In that case, the Court laid out a burden-shifting paradigm wherein the burden of production of evidence shifts between the employee and the management. Initially, the employee bears the burden of producing evidence that demonstrates a <i>prima facie</i> case of discrimination. Once an employee proves the elements of a <i>prima facie</i> case, the burden of production shifts to the employer to articulate a legitimate, non-discriminatory reason for management's action. Once a reason is articulated by management, the burden of production shifts back to the employee to prove that management’s reason is a pretext for discrimination or not worthy of belief. <a href="viewpage.html?_Page=LawOpinionsResearch_OpinionSCOTUS#caseBurdine" target="_blank"><i>Tex. Dep't of Comm. Affairs v. Burdine,</i> 450 U.S. 248 (1981)</a>. At all times, the burden of proof remains with the employee to provide discrimination by a preponderance of the evidence. Based upon the well-settled principles of evidence law, explained by the Court in <i>Burdine</i>, “The nature of the burden that shifts to the defendant should be understood in light of the plaintiff's ultimate and intermediate burdens. The ultimate burden of persuading the trier of fact that the defendant intentionally discriminated against the plaintiff remains at all times with the plaintiff.” Burdine, 450 U.S. at 453. See generally 9 J. Wigmore, Evidence § 2489 (3d ed. 1940) (the burden of persuasion “never shifts”).

Additionally, the EEOC Guidelines, vol. 2, §8-II.B.2, defines retalition: when a worker engages in protected activity if he or she “explicitly or implicitly communicates to his or her employer . . . a belief that its activity constitutes a form of employment discrimination;” such protected activity includes: (1) threatening to file charge or other formal complaint alleging discrimination; (2) complaining to anyone (including union official, co-worker, attorney or newspaper reporter) about alleged discrimination, and even non-verbal acts (such as picketing or engaging in production slowdown); (3) refusing to obey order based on reasonable belief that it is discriminatory; and (4) requesting accommodation of disability or religious belief). Further, the EEOC Guidelines, vol. 2, §8-II.C.2, makes it clear that protected “participation” includes testifying, assisting, or preparing an affidavit in conjunction with a proceeding or investigation under Title VII, ADEA, EPA, or ADA, without regard to whether the allegations are valid or reasonable.

However, where the Agency has articulated a legitimate, nondiscriminatory reason for the personnel action at issue, the factual inquiry can proceed directly to the third step of the McDonnell Douglas analysis, the ultimate issue of whether complainant has shown by a preponderance of the evidence that the Agency’s actions were motivated by discrimination. See U.S. Postal Service Board of Governors v. Aikens, 460 U.S. 711, 713-714 (1983); Hernandez v. Department of Transportation, EEOC Request No. 05900159 (June 28, 1990); Peterson v. Department of Health and Human Services, EEOC Request No. 05900467 (June 8, 1990); Washington v. Department of the Navy, EEOC Petition No. 03900056 (May 31, 1990).

Based upon a review of all of the evidence, the Complainant failed to show that the Agency’s legitimate, nondiscriminatory reasons was a pretext. Pretext can be demonstrated by “showing such weaknesses, implausibilities, inconsistencies, incoherencies, or contradictions in the [Agency’s] proffered legitimate reasons for its action that a reasonable fact finder could rationally find them unworthy of credence.” Dalesandro v. United Stated Postal Service, EEOC Appeal No. 01A50250 (January 30, 2006) (citing Morgan v. Hilti, Inc., 108 F3d 1319, 1323 (10th Cir. 1997)).

The Complainant’s subjective belief regarding the impropriety of the Agency’s actions, however genuine, does not constitute evidence of pretext or provide a basis for remedial relief. See Mroz v. Department of Defense, EEOC Appeal No. 01A33187 (January 23, 2004).

B. Reprisal

As previously stated, to establish a prima facie case of reprisal discrimination, the Complainant must show that: (1) he was engaged in a protected activity; (2) the defendant was aware of the protected activity; (3) he suffered a materially adverse action; and (4) there is a causal connection between his protected activity and the materially adverse action.

Federal law prohibits retaliation for opposing any practice made unlawful by Title VII of the Civil Rights Act (Title VII) (42 U.S.C. 2000e et seq.), the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) (29 U.S.C. 621 et seq.), the Equal Pay Act (29 U.S.C. 206(d)), or the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. 791 et seq.) or for participating in an administrative or judicial proceedings under those statutes. 29 C.F.R. § 1614.101(b).

This means that under the law, an employee or applicant is protected from reprisal for participation in the EEO process and from reprisal for opposition to an unlawful employment practice.

Claims in which disparate treatment is alleged are adjudicated under the standards set forth by the U.S. Supreme Court in <i>McDonnell Douglas v. Green,</i> 411 U.S. 792, 802 (1973). In that case, the Court laid out a burden-shifting paradigm wherein the burden of production of evidence shifts between the employee and the management. Initially, the employee bears the burden of producing evidence that demonstrates a <i>prima facie</i> case of discrimination. Once an employee proves the elements of a <i>prima facie</i> case, the burden of production shifts to the employer to articulate a legitimate, non-discriminatory reason for management's action. Once a reason is articulated by management, the burden of production shifts back to the employee to prove that management’s reason is a pretext for discrimination or not worthy of belief. <i>Tex. Dep't of Comm. Affairs v. Burdine,</i> 450 U.S. 248, 254-55 (1981). At all times, the burden of proof remains with the employee to provide discrimination by a preponderance of the evidence. Based upon the well-settled principles of evidence law, explained by the Court in <i>Burdine</i>, “The nature of the burden that shifts to the defendant should be understood in light of the plaintiff's ultimate and intermediate burdens. The ultimate burden of persuading the trier of fact that the defendant intentionally discriminated against the plaintiff remains at all times with the plaintiff.” Burdine, 450 U.S. at 453. See generally 9 J. Wigmore, Evidence § 2489 (3d ed. 1940) (the burden of persuasion “never shifts”).

Cuando el padre de un niño que requiere atención especial tiene sentimientos encontrados por su responsabilidad en cuanto a la causa o cura o cuidado del mismo, su comportamiento podría mostrar signos de culpabilidad, protección extrema o falta de ella.  Para ayudar a resolver estos problemas los padres, y quizá hasta los niños podrían beneficiarse de la terapia.  Cuando un padre con sentimientos de culpabilidad comparte la responsabilidad, él o ella podría sentirse tanto amenazado como deprimido, sobre todo cuando el comportamiento del padre que presta los cuidados es cuestionado. Cuando un padre trata de controlar los cuidados del niño excluyendo al otro padre, esto podría significar que siente una profunda necesidad de compensar el evento trágico que provocó alguna forma de discapacidad física o mental. 

Si el padre tiene muy baja estima o no le encuentra significado a su vida, las necesidades del niño le pueden dar significado a esa vida, que de otra forma estaría insatisfecha. Si a causa de estos sentimientos de fondo, el niño está siendo reprimido, el padre debe ser alentado a recibir asesoramiento y educación para el cuidado del niño a fin de desarrollar y fortalecer "el yo propio", y que el niño no salga herido.  El auto-desarrollo puede incluir lectura, tomar días libres, ejercicio, dieta y posiblemente un grupo de apoyo en donde otros padres en situaciones similares puedan compartir experiencias, ideas, apoyo y sabiduría.

El rechazar abiertamente a un niño con necesidades especiales, donde el padre renuncia a cualquier tipo de responsabilidad, afecto o interés, puede ser otro síntoma de sentimiento de culpa. Podría ser difícil, más no imposible, el convencer a un padre con esa actitud para que se haga responsable del niño sin la ayuda de terapia.  Como el padre podría sentirse avergonzado del niño o quizá no admita que le tiene miedo o disgusto, sería prudente el limitar el tiempo que pase con el niño hasta que esta situación mejore.  La mejor manera de reconciliar a un padre es por medio de la aceptación, la comprensión y la amabilidad, así el niño tendrá dos padres amorosos.

La razón por la que el niño tiene alguna discapacidad podría ser importante, por ejemplo, si dicha discapacidad fue causada por un defecto hereditario del padre o por el comportamiento de la madre durante el embarazo al usar drogas o alcohol. Dependiendo de la causa, uno u ambos padres podrían ser sobreprotectores con el niño, como el estar siempre cuidándolo, preocupados por él, o no permitirle que juegue con otros en actividades normales como andar en patineta o jugar fútbol.

Otras formas de problemas asociados a un niño con discapacidad pueden incluir el no mantenerse a sí misma, o ignorar los deberes familiares o de trabajo.  Podría haber también una pérdida de cuidado personal e incluso actitudes auto-destructivas y comportamientos posiblemente adictivos como alcohol, drogas (legales e ilegales), comida (atracarse, comer demasiado, anorexia) u otros problemas.
